title: Boyd hopes to make most of final games
text:
Boyd hopes to make most of final games Daniel Mahe , Beaumont Enterprise Published 8:04 am, Monday, October 26, 2015 Image 1 of / 1 Close Image 1 of 1 Josh Boyd looks to pass during the game between the Ozen Panthers and the Vidor Pirates at Pirate Stadium in Vidor, Friday October 9th, 2015 - photo provided by Kyle Ezell Josh Boyd looks to pass during the game between the Ozen Panthers and the Vidor Pirates at Pirate Stadium in Vidor, Friday October 9th, 2015 - photo provided by Kyle Ezell Boyd hopes to make most of final games 1 / 1 Back to Gallery 
With Ozen sliding to 1-4 in district play after Friday's loss to Port Neches – Groves, the high school football career of Panthers quarterback Josh Boyd appears to be two games from ending. 
Don't expect opposing coaches in District 22-5A to shed any tears. 
A three-year starter, the highly athletic Boyd has gained plenty of recognition from district coaches, being named Newcomer of the Year after his sophomore season and first-team all-district quarterback as a junior. 
His dual threat capabilities have also merited plenty of game planning attention by opposing defensive coordinators and kept defensive units on edge. 
Boyd will likely merit more district honors this season, emerging as the premier dual threat quarterback in the district, amassing almost 1,900 yards of total offense and accounting for 14 touchdowns through eight games. 
"I think if you can throw the ball and do a pretty good job of it, it makes you dangerous," said Ozen coach David Suggs , "and when you can run, too, it puts a lot of strain on defenses." 
Boyd's passing has generated 1,320 yards of offense for a team that has gouged opponents for big chunks of yardage, but been unable to translate its offensive explosiveness into enough wins to be a playoff contender. 
Boyd thinks some poor decision making, especially in the passing game, has kept Ozen from fulfilling its potential. 
"Interceptions, they're going to come," Boyd said. "You're going to have bad reads. As long as I don't make turnovers, we should be successful. It's really not the turnovers, it's the decisions that I make or other people make. I'm mad at the decisions, not (at) what's happened. I know what I'm capable of and I try to make those plays happen." 
Often it's Boyd's legs that are his primary playmaking tool. He considers himself a more gifted runner than passer and enjoys the chance to take off when he sees an opening. 
"I feel like when I run, I can't be stopped," Boyd said. "I like for them to try to tackle me. I like when I make a move and they miss. That makes me feel like I've done something. I like taking my highlight reel home and watching those plays." 
Boyd, who has rushed for 572 rushing yards and four touchdowns, tries to replicate the style of play of Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton – his role model. 
"(Newton) can run and throw the ball," Boyd said. "I feel like he carries the team on his back, and that's the kind of leader I admire." 
Boyd, a verbal basketball commit to Northwestern State, believes his role as a quarterback and point guard have challenged him to be a leader. 
"As a quarterback and the No. 1 and No. 2 guard in basketball, he's always been in that leadership role, where he's had to do things for the team," Suggs said. 
When asked how he'd like to be remembered after his football career comes to an end, Boyd expressed hope for his athleticism and potential. 
"Really, just being unstoppable and just being a leader," Boyd said. "Just being me." Southeast Texas sports news
